Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by b-mehta.
Probably @eric-wieser wants to have a look
I am not a fan of the import changes.

> My preference would be to put this in before #15072; @YaelDillies, are you happy to help resolve conflicts in the other PR if they go in that order?

That's my preference too, especially since there is so much of APAP waiting on this PR to be merged. I am of course happy to resolve conflicts in the other PR

:v: YaelDillies can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors merge

bors r-

Sorry. The discussion wasn't finished
Canceled.

@YaelDillies thanks for the offer of help. I appreciate anything you can provide. While I dislike reforming (what I view as) bad design, I understand you have things to move forward. 

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10417896231/job/28852981421)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10417896231/job/28852981189)

maintainer merge
bors d+

The changes here appear sensible and I agree they are useful in practice. I'd like someone else to double-check the instance changes are usable.

maintainer merge
My preference would be to put this in before #15072; @YaelDillies, are you happy to help resolve conflicts in the other PR if they go in that order?
bors d+
Let's name the lemma in question here: which is the specific one that you want to use it earlier than?
This should migrated to a test.

I created a new file under `test` and wrote
```
import Mathlib.Algebra.Algebra.Rat

/-- The two `Algebra  ` instances should coincide. -/
example : algebraRat = Algebra.id  := rfl
```
and it failed  

Turns out `algebraRat` was a bound variable as we haven't turned off auto-implicit in the `test` folder
Wouldn't a better solution be priorities? Also below.
Uh, maybe you're right, but I have been using this `nolint simpNF` pattern for a while so there will be a lot of occurrences to be fixed if you truly believe this is a better solution.
I think anything we should need about positivity should be in a separate file.
This seems like a big change in the import structure.

I know why this is necessary and I will say two things:
1. It's avoidable in a way that doesn't involve unnecessarily splitting files
2. I am working on this way, but it's definitely a later PR and I don't really want to get into the weeds of that now
Given the current design, I don't really want `NNRat` to go first before `Rat`.

Sorry, I don't understand this complaint. `NNRat` should always be earlier than `Rat` since it's used in `Semifield` while `Rat` is used in `Field` only.

Oh I guess you mean "the current design of `NNRat` as a subtype of `Rat`" in which case I shall reply "That design needs to be changed for independent reasons anyway, and I am willing to make it happen soon".

Subtype of `Rat` is fine in and of itself. But `NNRat.Defs` imports way too much of bundled ordered algebra classes to do what it needs to do. I'd prefer that gets fixed before we add more on top of it.
`Data.NNRat.Defs` is already imported in `Data.Rat.Cast.Defs` on master, so I do not understand your comment
Sorry, I kinda lost this. I already have a PR disconnecting the basics of `NNRat.Defs` #15072 from bundled ordered algebra that this might conflict with. Can we wait until that gets sorted out?
I think you need to inline `castHom` here, otherwise you get defeq-but-not-reducible-defeq diamonds. (cc @mattrobball)
I am guessing that `castHom` semi-reducible?
Oh, because `Algebra` also implements a coercion... I will make `castHom` reducible, since that's how we use it in practice anyway
Arguably, `RingHomClass.toNNRatLinearMapClass` would be a more accurate name.
Yes, true

```suggestion
1. There is a significant portion of the library which needs the early lemma to be available via
   `simp` and which doesn't have access to the more general lemmas.
2. The more general lemmas have more complicated typeclass assumptions, causing rewrites with them
   to be slower.
```
Uh, that doesn't respect the "indent by two spaces" rule. We don't right-flush anything else, eg in `calc` syntax

Ultimately what matters is whether our markdown formatter allows this.

... which I guess also doesn't matter because `library_note`s don't yet render anywhere:.

```suggestion
early lemma to be tagged `@[simp high]` (rather than `@[simp, nolint simpNF]` or un`@[simp]`ed):
```

I think we usually avoid abbreviations here?
```suggestion
library_note "specialised high priority simp lemma" /--
```
and at the references.

```suggestion
It sometimes happens that a `@[simp]` lemma declared early in the library can be proved by `simp` using
```

On second thoughts, let's leave this can of worms closed for now:
```suggestion
def castHom :  +*  where
```
We can fix it in a later PR.

idem
```suggestion
def castHom : 0 +*  where
```

```suggestion
/-- If monoid with zero homs `f` and `g` from `` agree on the integers then they are equal.
```

```suggestion
/-- If monoid with zero homs `f` and `g` from `` agree on the positive naturals and `-1` then
```
Do we have the `zpow` version somewhere else?
Yes, `NNRat.cast_zpow` in `Data.Rat.Cast.CharZero`
Can you put this in the instance_diamonds folder?
I think this might be `eq_iff'`?
Doesn't feel like a huge golf to me, but okay
